trans-unit.source: Enables forms authentication with client application services.
You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication.
To enable forms authentication, you configure your application to use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).

After configuration, you can validate users by calling the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Forms authentication requires that the user specify their credentials through login controls provided by your application.
You can retrieve the credentials and pass them to the <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
You can also pass in empty strings or `null` to use a credentials provider.
A credentials provider is an <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider> implementation specified in your application configuration file.

You will typically implement the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider.GetCredentials%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to display a login dialog box and return a populated <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationCredentials> object.
Using a credentials provider enables you to share a single login dialog box among multiple applications.

The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method authenticates users through the login service indicated by the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property.

The value of the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property is typically retrieved from the application configuration file along with other configuration values.
For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).

If the user is successfully authenticated, the service provider sets the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to a new <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientRolePrincipal> object that contains a new <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity> object that contains the user information.

If a <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider> is configured for your application, you can use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientRolePrincipal> object to retrieve user role information from the roles service.

You can retrieve a reference to the current <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> instance through the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.Provider%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.

You can use the membership provider reference to call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method directly.

Additionally, you will need the membership provider reference to call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Logout%2A> method, which is not available in the <xref:System.Web.Security.MembershipProvider> base class.
You cannot use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class to create, delete, or modify membership information.
To create, delete, or modify users, you must change the configuration of the login service on the server.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider"></xref> class.
This property is not used by this class.
Setting this property has no effect.
The name of the application using the custom membership provider.
This method is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.

Initializes the provider.

The [!INCLUDE[vstecasp](~/includes/vstecasp-md.md)] extensibility model calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Initialize%2A> method to initialize the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> using information in your application configuration file.
This method recognizes the following authentication service configuration attributes:
For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).
The friendly name of the provider.
A collection of name/value pairs representing the provider-specific attributes specified in the configuration for this provider.
name is `null`.
-or-
config is `null`.
name is empty.
-or-
config contains an unrecognized value.
This <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider"></xref> has already been initialized.
Logs out the user.

The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Logout%2A> method clears all authentication cookies from the cookie cache and resets the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to a <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsPrincipal> object that contains the current <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsIdentity>.
After you call this method, the current user is no longer authenticated for client application services.

This means that you cannot retrieve roles through the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider> class and settings through the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientSettingsProvider> class.
However, because the user might have a valid Windows identity, you might still receive a `true` value from code such as the following: `Thread.CurrentPrincipal.Identity.IsAuthenticated`.

To determine whether the user is authenticated for client application services, confirm that the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal.Identity%2A> property value of the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal> retrieved through the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A> property is a <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity> reference.
Then, check the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity.IsAuthenticated%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.

To reauthenticate the current user, call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method or the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
The <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.ConnectivityStatus.IsOffline"></xref> property value is `false` and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.
This property is not used by this class.
The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class always provides three password attempts.
You cannot modify the provider to change the number of password attempts.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
The number of invalid password attempts allowed before the membership user is locked out.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Always zero.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Always one.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
The number of minutes in which a maximum number of invalid password or password-answer attempts are allowed before the membership user is locked out.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
The format for storing passwords in the store data.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Always "*".
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Always `false`.
This property is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Always `false`.

Not used.
Not used.
Not applicable.
This method always throws an exception.
Always thrown.
Gets or sets the URI of the authentication service.

You can set the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property in your application code, but you will typically set the value in your application configuration file.
This enables you to change the service location without recompiling your code.
The authentication service URI.
When getting this property, no service URI was found in the application configuration file, and this property has not been previously set.
This method is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Not used.
Not applicable.
This method always throws an exception.
Always thrown.
This method is not used by this class.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.
Not used.
Always thrown.
Occurs when the user is validated.
This event occurs only after the user is successfully validated.
You can use this event to update your application to reflect the current user.

For example, you can use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.UserValidatedEventArgs.UserName%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to display the user name in your application user interface (UI).
You can silently revalidate users by calling the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity.RevalidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Therefore, you should avoid using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.UserValidated> event to display intrusive UI.
For example, you should not use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.UserValidated> event to display a welcome dialog box.
Authenticates a user by using the specified user name and password.
You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication.

To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Alternatively, you can call this method directly, as shown in the Example section.
Forms authentication requires that the user specify their credentials through login controls provided by your application.
You can retrieve the credentials and pass them to the <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
You can also pass in empty strings or `null` to use a credentials provider.
For more information, see [How to: Implement User Login with Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-implement-user-login-with-client-application-services.md).

The name of the user to authenticate, or <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref> or `null` to retrieve credentials from the <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider"></xref> implementation that this application is configured to use.
The password of the user to authenticate.
`true` if the user was authenticated; otherwise, `false`.
The <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.ConnectivityStatus.IsOffline"></xref> property value is `false` and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.
Authenticates a user by using the specified user name and password, optionally storing a hash of the password in the local data cache.
You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication.

To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Alternatively, you can call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method directly.
You can call this overload to pass in a `rememberMe` value in addition to the `username` and `password` values.
The name of the user to authenticate.
The password of the user to authenticate.

`true` to store a hash of the password in the local data cache for offline use and for automatic reauthentication when the user authentication cookie expires; `false` to disable offline login or to require users to reauthenticate when the cookie expires.
`true` if the user was authenticated; otherwise, `false`.
The <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.ConnectivityStatus.IsOffline"></xref> property value is `false` and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.
Authenticates a user at the specified service URI by using the specified user name and password.
You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication.

To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Alternatively, you can call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method directly.
You can call this overload to access an authentication service at the location specified by the `serviceUri` parameter.

Using this overload is an alternative to setting the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property and calling the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29> overload.
The name of the user to authenticate.
The password of the user to authenticate.
The URI of the authentication service to use.
`true` if the user was authenticated; otherwise, `false`.
The <xref href="System.Web.ClientServices.ConnectivityStatus.IsOffline"></xref> property value is `false` and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.
